STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 25, 2022
Franchesca Vega
Wayne County DHHS - Southcentral
1801 East Canfield
Detroit, MI 48207
RE: License #: CP820201496
Wayne County DHHS - Southcentral
1801 East Canfield
Detroit, MI 48207
Dear Ms. Vega:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 3/4/2022.
An Exit Conference was held with you on 3/14/2022. Due to the violations of applicable
licensing rules, sections of the contract and MISEP requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat non-
compliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 860-0787.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP820201496
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Wayne County DHHS - Southcentral
Facility Address: 1801 East Canfield
Detroit, MI 48207
Facility Telephone #: (313) 578-5102
Original Issuance Date: 09/03/1993
Service Types:
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s):02/28/2022; 03/01/2022; 03/03/2022 & 03/04/2022

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
One of eight employee records reviewed for employees
employed over one year showed the employee’s performance
evaluation for 2021 was completed late on 2/6/2022.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the
time of the change in placement and the needs that remain to
be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services
Four of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance as required by rule (a) and (b).
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3 months before
being placed in foster care or a new physical examination shall
be completed within 30 calendar days after being placed in
foster care.
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
4

Two of eight open foster child record reviewed did not show
compliance related to (i) and (ii):
(i):
 One record showed the child’s medical due by 5/30/2021
was completed three days late on 6/2/202.
(ii):
 The second record showed the child medical due by
11/21/2021 was completed a month late on 12/21/2021.
Repeat Violation: Renewal- January 2021.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
One of eight open foster child record reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s dental due by 1/30/2022.
Repeat Violation: Renewal-January 2021.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Five of 18 updated service plans (USP) reviewed were late.
 One child’s 1/14/2021-4/4/2021 USP was completed one
day late on 4/5/2021.
 A second child’s 6/7/2021-9/4/2021 USP was completed
13 days late on 9/17/2021. This child’s 9/5/2021-
12/3/2021 USP was completed 1 day late on 12/4/2021.
 A third child’s 1/16/2021-4/15/2021 USP was completed
2 days late on 4/17/2021. This child 4/16/2021-7/14/2021
USP was completed 1 day late on 7/15/2021.
Repeat Violation: Renewal-January 2021.
5

R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404 (4).
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (c) as required by the rule.
R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(h) The child management plan to be used by the foster
parent.
In two of eight open foster child records reviewed the initial
service plan documented that the foster parent/caregiver was
not to use physical discipline, or was to abide by agency’s
policy, but not what specific behavior management plan the
foster parent/caregiver was to use with the child.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(g) A child management plan which includes any changes made
since the previous plan and which is to be used by the foster
parents.
In five of eight open foster child records reviewed the updated
service plan or plans documented that the foster
parent/caregiver was not to use physical discipline, or was to
abide by agency’s policy, but not what specific behavior
management plan the foster parent/caregiver was to use with
the child.
R 400. 12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum
(b) Agency social services worker shall visit the foster child and
the foster parent in the foster parent’s home at least once every
month.
6

In one of eight open foster child records reviewed the record did
not show documentation of March 2021 home visit with child
and caregiver.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
MISEP 6.16 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker's caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve each
service plan. The plan can be approved only after the supervisor
has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which can be the
monthly meeting.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of a June 2021 worker/supervisor meeting.
ISEP 6.19 (5) (c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (commitment 69).
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker's supervisor, the parent(s}, and the child(ren),
if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both
are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service
plan shall include an explanation of the steps taken to
involve them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be
taken to secure their participation in services.
Three of 21 service plans reviewed did not show documentation
of the birth parent’s signature.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
7

community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following table.
Seven of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the policy:
 One record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the child’s USP period 12/12/20-3/9/2021 or 3/10/2021-
6/5/2021. One was held after the first USP reporting
period, on 3/30/2021; and sooner than required for the
second USP reporting period, on 4/21/2021.
 A second record did not show documentation of an FTM
for the child’s 10/22/202-11/19/2021 ISP; one was
completed after the period on 11/24/2021. Nor did the
record show an FTM for the child’s 11/20/2021-2/17/2022
USP.
 A third record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the child’s 3/9/2021-6/6/2021 USP. One was completed
sooner than required on 4/1/2021.
 A fourth record did not show documentation of an FTM
for the child’s 12/16/2020-3/15/2021 USP. Nor the child’s
9/10/2021-12/8/2021 USP.
 A fifth record did not show documentation for an FTM for
the child’s 1/4/2021-4/4/2021 USP.
 A sixth record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the child’s ISP. Nor the child’s 10/27/2021-1/7/2022
USP.
 A seventh record did not show documentation of an FTM
for the child’s 1/16/2021-4/15/2021 or 4/16/2021-
7/14/2021 USP.
Repeat Violation: Renewal-January 2021.
FOM 722-08 Case Service Plans- Overview, Types, And Timeframes.
Supervisor Approval:
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
One of 21 services plans did not show compliance
 The child’s: 6/7/2021-9/4/2021 USP, completed on
9/17/2021, was approved seven days late on 10/8/2021.
8

Repeat Violation: Renewal-January 2021; cited under FOM
722-09.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Ten of 21 service plans (for five open foster child records)
reviewed did not show compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of the
caregiver’s signature on the treatment plan for the child’s
12/20/2020- 2/9/2021: and 9/2/2021-11/25/2021 USP.
 A second record did not show documentation of the
caregiver’s signature on the treatment plan for the child’s
7/2/2021- 9/7/2021 USP. The treatment plan for this
child’s 1/4/201-4/4/2021 and 9/8/2021-12/6/2021 USP’s
were signed by the caregiver on 8/26/2021 and
2/25/2022 respectively. Both signatures were more than
30 days after the respective report date.
 A third record showed documentation of the caregiver’s
signature on the child’s 6/29/2021-7/28/2021 ISP
treatment plan and next two USPs (7/29/2021-
10/26/2021; 10/27/2021-1/2/2022) were all signed by the
caregiver on 2/25/202. All were more than 30 days after
the report date.
 A fourth record did not show documentation of the
caregiver’s signature on the child’s 9/5/2021-12/3/2021
USP treatment plan.
 A fifth record did not show documentation of the
caregiver’s signature on the child’s 4/16/2021-7/14/2021
USP treatment plan.
FOM 722-08 E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
Completion Requirements:
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
9

MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
change.
 Within three business days of foster care or juvenile
justice program case closure.
 Three days prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement
change.
Six of six closed child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 Two records did not show documentation of a DHS-69 for
the respective child’s 6/10/2021 and 7/30/2021case
closure.
 A third and fourth records did not show documentation of
a DHS-69 for the respective child’s 2/19/2021 and
6/17/2021, return home. Nor the respective child’s
4/23/2021 and 9/17/2021 case closure.
 A fifth record did not show documentation of a DHS-69
for the child’s 10/20/2021 return home. Additionally, the
child’s 2/2/2022 DHS-69 for case closure was completed
more than three business day after on 2/14/2022.
 A sixth record did not show a clear documentation of a
timely DHS-69 for the child’s reported 8/11/2021
replacement. The DHS-69 was dated prior to the
indicated replacement date; and it denoted a 9/15/2021
date as to when some notifications occurred.
FOM 722-15 Discharge documents.
The caseworker must provide the following documents to the
child's legal parent/guardian, or to the youth if the youth is age
18 or older or has been legally emancipated, at the time of
closure:
 A certified copy of the child's birth certificate (retain a
copy in the case record).
 The child's social security card. Note: In cases where the
social security number has been verified and
documented per policy, the caseworker must make
efforts to obtain a social security card. •
 A copy of the child's updated DHS-221, Medical
Passport; see FOM 801, Health Services for Children in
Foster Care.
 Any available education records; see FOM 723,
Educational Services.
 DHS-945, Financial Aid Verification of Court/State Ward
Status, for youth ages 13 or older at the time of closure.
Note: The DHS-945 must be completed by a MDHHS
10

caseworker. PAFC caseworkers must request a
completed DHS-945 from the MDHHS monitoring
caseworker.
Two of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One did not show documentation that the information
required by the policy were provided to the birth
parent.
 A second did not show documentation that education
information was provided.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport.
Updated Medical Passport:
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward; Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement;
and at reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each
placement and quarterly.
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
consistent documentation that the medical passport was
completed quarterly and provided to the caregiver.
FOM 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and Developmental Need of
Children under supervision of MDHHS.
All children entering foster care are required to have a mental
health screening within 30 days of removal. The screening
instrument must be completed by a person who knows the child
best, before the child's Early Periodic, Screening, Diagnostic,
and Treatment (EPSTD)/well child exam.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the policy.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12404(7)(a)(iii)-(v)Placement
The agency was apprised it shall consistently document these required
11

characteristics timely.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Nothing this inspection
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
This corrective action plan related to the agency’s January 2021 Renewal Inspection
where it received the following citations:
 R400.12413(1)(c)- Medical and dental policy.
 R400.12413(1)(f)- Medical and dental policy.
 R400.12418(2)(b)- Development of service plans.
 FOM 722-06B- Family team meeting.
 FOM 722-06I Sibling visitation
 FOM 722-08- Initial service plan approval.
 FOM 722-09- Updated service plan approval.
The agency has effectively completed tools identified in its corrective action plan but
were not totally successful with completion of the corrective action plan related to all
rule compliance. They received repeat violations as indicated in this report.
DCWL ANAYLST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
There were no safety alerts this inspection.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
______________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date 3/21/2022
Licensing Consultant
12

Approved By:
March 25, 2022
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
13
